title: R45248
content: Under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), agencies must submit reports to Congress and the Government Accountability Office (GAO) before rules can take effect. Major rules require additional time for Congressional review, with GAO assessing agency compliance. Congress can use expedited procedures to overturn rules, primarily in the Senate. Under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), expedited procedures in the Senate allow for quick overturning of rules. A joint resolution disapproving a rule can be passed with a simple majority, with no amendments permitted. If both houses pass the resolution and the President signs it (or Congress overrides a veto), the rule will not take effect. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows for quick overturning of rules through expedited procedures in the Senate. If a joint resolution disapproving a rule is passed by both houses and signed by the President (or if Congress overrides the President's veto), the rule will not take effect. The CRA reinstates the status quo prior to the rule's issuance and prohibits the issuance of a rule in substantially the same form unless authorized by a subsequent law. The CRA applies to rules issued by most executive branch entities, as defined by the APA.
